column4: Is it easy to install Fiesty to an external USB drive, and if so, will grub still load up during booting?
Would instally Ubuntu to an external USB drive be any different than installing to an extra internal drive?
yes, because grub will look for its menu.lst on a drive that might not be present
Ahhh...So, in other words, if the drive wasn't present it wouldn't just proceed to the XP drive...It will look for grub and get stuck?
grub will try to look on the (not present) sda1 for it's menu.lst, won't find it and throw error 17
So, is that a difficult/impossible setup?

no, it just requires a separate partiton for grub, or not using grub at all to boot the USB-ubuntu. there might even be BIOS's that can boot from USB, so grub can be installed to the USB sticks MBR, because the hd's MBR is not looked at
If my bios would support booting to USB How do I setup the ubuntu install properly?
No I mean, I know how to do the install itself, but is there some particular setup I need w/ the seperate grub partition or anything?
that depends on your bios. You'll need the alternate install CD to determine where grub gets installed in the process. Desktop CD can't do that
make sure to use tmpfs for /tmp and avoid a swap-partiton on the USB-disk... flash memory does not like to be written too often
Out of curiosity, reinstalling ubuntu desktop won't reinstall gnome?
no it would just check if all the default packages are installed. a metapackage does nothing more than having a predefined set of dependencies
So what would you do if you somehow corrupted gnome?
dpkg-reconfigure or apt-get install --reinstall the package off the app which got corupt
avahi-daemon and network-manager are my favourite victims to blame
I've walked that path...I am in a little bit of a more quirky situation
